fields.description: Lincoln Davenport Chafee, born March 26, 1953, is an American politician from Rhode Island who has served as the Mayor of Warwick (1993–1999), a U.S. Senator (1999–2007) and as the 74th Governor of Rhode Island (2011–2015).

Hillary Clinton was born on October 26, 1947, in Chicago, Illinois. She married Bill Clinton in 1975. She served as first lady from 1993 to 2001, and then as a U.S. senator from 2001 to 2009. In early 2007, Clinton announced her plans to run for the presidency. During the 2008 Democratic primaries, she conceded her nomination when it became apparent that Barack Obama held a majority of the delegate vote. After winning the national election, Obama appointed Clinton as secretary of state. She was sworn in January 2009 and served in that position until 2013. In the spring of 2015, she announced her plans to again run for the U.S. presidency.

Martin Joseph O'Malley, born January 18, 1963, is an American politician who served as the 61st Governor of Maryland, from 2007 to 2015. Prior to being elected as Governor, he served as the Mayor of Baltimore from 1999 to 2007, having previously served as a Baltimore City Councilor from 1991 to 1999. A member of the Democratic Party, he served as the Chair of the Democratic Governors Association from 2011 to 2013. O'Malley publicly announced his candidacy for the 2016 presidential election on May 30, 2015, in Baltimore, Maryland, and filed his candidacy form seeking the Democratic Party nomination with the Federal Election Commission on May 29, 2015.

Born in 1941, politician Bernie Sanders started out his career as the mayor of Burlington, Vermont. He served four terms as the leader of Vermont's biggest city from 1981 to 1989. Sanders then moved on to the national political arena by winning a seat in the House of Representatives. From 1991 to 2007, he distinguished himself as one of the country's few independent legislators. In 2007, Sanders won election to the U.S. Senate and was reelected in 2012. He announced his plans to run for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2015.

James Henry "Jim" Webb, Jr., born February 9, 1946, is an American politician and author. He has served as a United States Senator from Virginia, Secretary of the Navy, Assistant Secretary of Defense, Counsel for the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and Marine Corps officer. In the private sector he has been an Emmy-award winning journalist, a filmmaker, and the author of ten books. In addition, he taught literature at the United States Naval Academy and was a Fellow at the Harvard Institute of Politics. As a member of the Democratic Party, Webb announced on November 19, 2014, that he was forming an exploratory committee to evaluate a run for President of the United States in 2016. On July 2, 2015, he announced that he would be joining the race for the Democratic nomination for President.

Born on February 11, 1953, in Midland, Texas, Jeb Bush is the son of George Bush, the 41st U.S. president, and the brother of George W. Bush, the 43rd U.S. president. Jeb Bush moved up the ranks in Florida politics in the 1980s and '90s before securing the state's governorship in 1998. The Republican remained as Florida's governor until 2007. The following year, many speculated that he'd run for the U.S. Senate, but that did not occur. In June 2015, Bush announced his run for the U.S. presidency.

Born in Miami, Florida in 1971, Marco Rubio is the son of Cuban immigrants. After earning a bachelor's degree from the University of Florida in 1993, he went to the University of Miami for his law degree. Rubio's political career began with his election to the West Miami City Commission in 1998. He was elected in the Florida House of Representatives the following year. In 2009, Rubio won his campaign for the U.S. Senate.

Scott Walker was born on November 2, 1967. He became interested in politics as a teenager, attended but did not graduate from college and worked in fundraising for several years. By the age of 25, he was a member of the Wisconsin State Assembly and quickly moved up the ranks, serving as a Milwaukee County executive and the state's governor. His fiscal conservatism launched him into the national spotlight in 2011, when he proposed eliminating most collective bargaining rights for state workers. Some Wisconsin residents demanded a recall election, which Walker won, making him the first governor in U.S. history to survive a recall election. Walker was subsequently elected to a second term in 2014, and in early 2015 began fundraising efforts for a potential run for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016.

Ben Carson was born in Detroit, Michigan, on September 18, 1951. His mother, though undereducated herself, pushed her sons to read and to believe in themselves. Carson went from being a poor student to receiving honors and he eventually attended medical school. As a doctor, he became the Director of Pediatric Neurosurgery at Johns Hopkins Hospital at age 33, and became famous for his ground-breaking work separating conjoined twins.

Born in Pennsylvania in 1963, Rand Paul became involved in politics in 1994, when he founded Kentucky Taxpayers United, a watchdog group that tracked taxation and spending in Kentucky until it dissolved in 2000. Rand Paul gained national attention when he campaigned for his father, Ron Paul, who was running for the Republican presidential nomination in 2008. He attracted a small but passionate following which helped him win the U.S. Senate seat for Kentucky in 2010. Paul is the first U.S. Senator to serve alongside a parent—his father Ron Paul—in the U.S. House of Representatives.

Michael Huckabee was born on August 24, 1955, in Hope, Arkansas. He unsuccessfully ran for the Senate in 1992. In 1993, he won a special election for lieutenant governor, then became governor when Jim Guy Tucker was convicted in events relating to Whitewater. Huckabee was elected to full terms in 1998 and 2002. He ran for the Republican nomination for president in 2008 but lost to John McCain. In 2015, Huckabee announced that he will run for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

Born on December 22, 1970, American conservative politician Ted Cruz grew up in Houston, Texas, earning his bachelor's at Princeton University and going on to Harvard Law School. Working as an attorney for some time, Cruz later served as an adviser on the 2000 presidential campaign of George W. Bush. In 2012 he won election to the U.S. Senate with the support of the Tea Party and took office the following year, going on to orchestrate a governmental shutdown in opposition to Obamacare. In 2015, he announced that he was running for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

Real estate developer Donald John Trump was born June 14, 1946, in Queens, New York. The rumors go his parents are well adjusted orangutans. To be fair, he never showed his birth certificate. In 1971 he became involved in large profitable building projects in Manhattan. He opened the Grand Hyatt in 1980, which made him the city's best known and most controversial developer. In 2004 Trump began starring in the hit NBC reality series The Apprentice, which also became an offshoot for The Celebrity Apprentice.

fields.max_label: Supports labeling and regulation of GMO products

fields.name: Drug Policy Alliance

fields.name: Partnership for Drug-Free Kids

fields.name: Phoenix House Foundation
fields.description: Helping individuals, families, and communities affected by substance abuse and dependency.

fields.name: SADD (National Office)
fields.description: To provide students with the best prevention tools possible to deal with issues of underage drinking, other drug use, impaired and risky driving and other destructive decisions.

fields.name: Alaska Conservation Foundation
fields.description: To preserve Alaska's environment.

fields.name: American Bird Conservancy
fields.description: Conserves native wild birds and their habitats throughout the Americas, safeguarding the rarest species, restoring habitats, and reducing threats, while building capacity in the bird conservation movement.

fields.name: American Farmland Trust
fields.description: To help farmers and ranchers protect their land, produce a healthier environment and build successful communities.

fields.name: American Forests
fields.description: Protects and restores forests, preserving the health of our planet and the well-being of its inhabitants.

fields.name: American Rivers
fields.description: Protects wild rivers, restores damaged rivers, and conserves clean water for people and nature.

fields.name: Arbor Day Foundation
fields.description: To engage in educational and charitable activities including officially promoting the annual observance of Arbor Day; inspiring people to plant, nurture, and celebrate trees; stimulating a worldwide program of tree and horticultural planting and care; advancing nature education and environmental education; and maintaining Arbor Day Farm, the estate of Arbor Day's founder, J. Sterling Morton.

fields.name: Center for Biological Diversity
fields.description: Works to secure a future for all species, great and small, hovering on the brink of extinction, through science, law and creative media, with a focus on protecting the lands, waters and climate that species need to survive.

fields.name: Chesapeake Bay Foundation
fields.description: To save the Chesapeake Bay.

fields.name: Conservation Fund

fields.name: Conservation International Foundation
fields.description: Building upon a strong foundation of science, partnership and field demonstration, empowers societies to responsibly and sustainably care for nature, our global biodiversity, for the well-being of humanity.

fields.name: Cousteau Society
fields.description: Dedicated to the protection and improvement of the quality of life for present and future generations. Educational activities directed toward members, classrooms, and the general public promote environmental awareness leading to sound decisions to protect and manage the world's resources.

fields.name: Defenders of Wildlife
fields.description: Habitat and species protection.

fields.name: Ducks Unlimited
fields.description: Conserves, restores, and manages wetlands and associated habitats for North America's waterfowl.

fields.name: Earth Island Institute
fields.description: To develop and support projects that counteract threats to the biological and cultural diversity that sustain the environment. Through education and activism, these projects promote the conservation, preservation, and restoration of the Earth.

fields.name: Earthjustice
fields.description: Uses the law to protect natural heritage, safeguard health, and promote a clean energy future.

fields.name: Earthworks
fields.description: Protecting communities and the environment from the adverse impacts of mineral and energy development while promoting sustainable solutions.

fields.name: Environmental Defense Action Fund
fields.description: To educate the public regarding environmental and conservation issues, and advocate legislation and policies that protect the environmental rights of all people.

fields.name: Environmental Defense Fund
fields.description: To preserve the natural systems on which all life depends; guided by science and economics, finds practical and lasting solutions to the most serious environmental problems.

fields.name: Environmental Working Group
fields.description: To conduct original, game-changing research that inspires people, businesses and governments to take action to protect human health and the environment.

fields.name: Food and Water Watch
fields.description: Conducts extensive research and public education to ensure the food, water and fish we consume is safe, accessible and sustainably produced.

fields.name: Friends of the Earth
fields.description: Defends the environment and champions a healthy and just world.

fields.name: Gaia-Movement Living Earth Green World Action USA
fields.description: To educate the general public on environmental matters and promote the environment on a worldwide basis.

fields.name: Greenpeace
fields.description: Greenpeace is an independent campaigning organization that uses peaceful direct action and creative communication to expose global environmental problems and promote solutions that are essential for a green and peaceful future.

fields.name: Greenpeace Fund
fields.description: To protect and preserve the environment through the funding of grants to other organizations.

fields.name: Izaak Walton League of America
fields.description: To conserve, restore and promote the sustainable use and enjoyment of our natural resources, including soil, air, woods, water and wildlife.

fields.name: Keep America Beautiful (National Office)
fields.description: To engage individuals in taking greater responsibility for improving their community environments.

fields.name: League of Conservation Voters
fields.description: Works to turn environmental values into national, state & local priorities; advocates for sound environmental laws & policies; holds elected officials accountable for their votes & actions; elects pro-environmental candidates who will champion our priority issues.

fields.name: League of Conservation Voters Education Fund
fields.description: Works to turn environmental values into national, state & local priorities; educates the public, media & elected officials about key environmental issues; works to increase voter participation in the democratic process; mobilizes a diverse network of activists to advocate for sound environmental policies.

fields.name: National Audubon Society
fields.description: To conserve and restore natural ecosystems, focusing on birds and other wildlife, for the benefit of humanity and the biological diversity of the earth.

fields.name: National Park Foundation
fields.description: The US Congress chartered the National Park Foundation to strengthen the connection between the American people and their National Parks by raising private funds, making strategic grants, creating innovative partnerships, and increasing public awareness.

fields.name: National Park Trust
fields.description: Preserving parks today; creating park stewards for tomorrow.

fields.name: National Parks Conservation Association
fields.description: To protect and enhance America's national parks for present and future generations.

fields.name: National Wildlife Federation
fields.description: To inspire Americans to protect wildlife for our children's future.

fields.name: Natural Resources Defense Council
fields.description: To safeguard the Earth: Its people, its plants and animals and the natural systems on which all life depends.

fields.name: Nature Conservancy
fields.description: Preserve plants, animals, and natural communities by protecting the lands and waters they need to survive.

fields.name: Ocean Conservancy
fields.description: To bring people together to find solutions for our water planet; educate and empower people to defend not only the ocean and its wildlife, but also the millions who earn their living from the ocean.

fields.name: Resources for the Future
fields.description: To improve environmental and natural resource policy making worldwide through social science research.

fields.name: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation
fields.description: To ensure the future of elk, other wildlife, their habitat and our hunting heritage; includes conserving habitat, promoting elk management, and educating members on conservation and hunting.

fields.name: Save the Redwoods League
fields.description: Protects and restores redwood forests and connects people with their peace and beauty so these wonders of the natural world flourish.

fields.name: Sierra Club
fields.description: To explore, enjoy, and protect the wild places of the earth; practice and promote responsible use of the earth's ecosystems and resources; educate and enlist humanity to protect and restore the quality of the natural and human environment; and use all lawful means to carry out these objectives.

fields.name: Sierra Club Foundation
fields.description: To help educate, inspire and empower humanity to preserve the natural and human environment by providing resources for charitable programs that protect and restore the environment.

fields.name: Student Conservation Association
fields.description: To build the next generation of conservation leaders and inspire lifelong stewardship of our environment and communities by engaging young people in hands-on service to the land.

fields.name: Trout Unlimited
fields.description: To conserve, protect, and restore North America's coldwater fisheries and their watersheds.

fields.name: Trust for Public Land

fields.name: Union of Concerned Scientists
fields.description: Puts rigorous independent science to work to solve the most pressing problems of our planet.

fields.name: Water.org
fields.description: To draw attention to the world's number one health problem, unsafe and inadequate water supplies, and to raise funds to help fight this immense problem - one community at a time.

fields.name: Waterkeeper Alliance
fields.description: Organized to serve as the umbrella group for other waterkeepers programs throughout north America and other countries. Focuses on citizen advocacy on the issues that affect our waterways.

fields.name: Wilderness Society
fields.description: To protect wilderness and inspire Americans to care for our wild places.

fields.name: Yosemite Conservancy
fields.description: Inspire people to support projects and programs that preserve and protect Yosemite National Park's resources and enrich the visitor experience.

fields.name: Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence
fields.description: Devoted to creating an America free from gun violence, where all Americans are safe at home, at school, at work, and in our communities.

fields.name: Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence
fields.description: Devoted to creating an America free from gun violence, where all Americans are safe at home, at school, at work, and in our communities.

fields.name: National Police Defense Foundation

fields.name: National Rifle Association

fields.name: National Rifle Association (NRA) Foundation
fields.description: Support of a wide range of firearm-related public interest activities of the National Rifle Association of America and other organizations that defend and foster the Second Amendment rights of all law-abiding Americans.

fields.name: ALS Association
fields.description: To lead the fight to cure and treat ALS through global, cutting-edge research.

fields.name: American Brain Tumor Association
fields.description: Advance the understanding and treatment of brain tumors with the goals of improving, extending and, ultimately, saving the lives of those impacted by a brain tumor diagnosis.

fields.name: American Diabetes Association
fields.description: To prevent and cure diabetes and to improve the lives of all people affected by diabetes.

fields.name: American Heart Association
fields.description: Building healthier lives, free of cardiovascular diseases and stroke.

fields.name: American Kidney Fund
fields.description: To fight kidney disease through direct financial support to patients in need; health education; and prevention efforts.

fields.name: American Leprosy Missions
fields.description: To serve as a channel of Christ's love to persons affected by leprosy and related conditions, helping them be healed in body and spirit and restored to lives of dignity and hope.

fields.name: American Liver Foundation
fields.description: To facilitate, advocate and promote education, support and research for the prevention, treatment and cure for liver disease.

fields.name: American Lung Association (National Office)

fields.name: American Parkinson Disease Association

fields.name: American Red Cross

fields.name: American Sexual Health Association

fields.name: Arthritis Foundation

fields.name: BrightFocus Foundation
fields.description: Seeks to save mind and sight by funding innovative research worldwide and by promoting better health through education.

fields.name: Children With Hair Loss
fields.description: Hair replacement for children with medically related hair loss.

fields.name: City of Hope

fields.name: Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America
fields.description: To cure Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, and to improve the quality of life of children and adults affected by these diseases.

fields.name: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation
fields.description: To cure cystic fibrosis and to provide all people with the disease the opportunity to lead full, productive lives by funding research and drug development, promoting individualized treatment, and ensuring access to high quality, specialized care.

fields.name: Defeat Diabetes Foundation
fields.description: The prevention, early identification and effective self-management of the global epidemic, diabetes.  Work with individuals and organizations worldwide through awareness, interactive and assistance programs.

fields.name: Diabetes Action Research and Education Foundation
fields.description: Committed to the prevention and treatment of diabetes and to the funding of innovative, promising research aimed at finding a cure for diabetes and diabetes related complications.

fields.name: Diabetes Research & Wellness Foundation
fields.description: To help find the cure for diabetes, and until that goal is achieved, to provide the care and self-management skills needed to combat the life-threatening complications of diabetes, and to promote public education about the causes, prevention, and treatment of the disease.

fields.name: Diabetes Research Institute Foundation
fields.description: To provide the Diabetes Research Institute (at the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine) with the funding necessary to cure diabetes now.

fields.name: Easter Seals (National Office)

fields.name: Epilepsy Foundation & Epilepsy Research Foundation

fields.name: First Candle (National Office)

fields.name: Hearing Health Foundation

fields.name: Heart Center of America

fields.name: JDRF International

fields.name: Lupus Research Institute

fields.name: MedicAlert Foundation United States

fields.name: Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research

fields.name: Project Cure

We do this by challenging medical orthodoxy and amplifying new voices within the health care reform debate through dissemination of letters, faxes, post cards, brochures, newsletters, websites, and other mass communication tools. Primary focus is on three distinct chronic disease conditions: Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, and prostate cancer.

fields.name: Salk Institute for Biological Studies
fields.description: The advancement and dissemination of knowledge relevant to the health and well-being of man. Performs research and advanced instruction in biology; the cause, prevention, and cure of diseases; and the factors and circumstances conducive to the fulfillment of man's biological potential.

fields.description: Provide pediatric specialty care without financial obligation to patients or their families.

fields.description: Civil rights organization working to achieve equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) Americans.

fields.name: Human Rights Campaign Foundation
fields.description: Research, advocacy and education to support and protect lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) individuals and families.

fields.name: Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund
fields.description: A national organization committed to achieving full recognition of the civil rights of lesbians, gay men, bisexuals, transgender people and those with HIV through impact litigation, education and public policy work.

fields.name: Trevor Project
fields.description: To end suicide among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning (LGBTQ) young people.

fields.name: American Life League
fields.description: Exists to serve God by helping to build a society that respects and protects individual innocent human beings from creation to death--without compromise, without exception, without apology.

fields.name: Center for Reproductive Rights
fields.description: Promoting and defending women's reproductive rights worldwide.

fields.name: Guttmacher Institute
fields.description: To advance sexual and reproductive health and rights through an interrelated program of research, policy analysis, and public education designed to generate new ideas, encourage enlightened public debate, and promote sound policy and program development.

fields.name: NARAL Pro Choice America (National Office)
fields.description: Promotion of social welfare and education of the public on matters related to reproductive rights.

fields.name: NARAL Pro-Choice America Foundation (National Office)
fields.description: To operate for the benefit of, to perform the educational and charitable functions of, and to carry out the educational and charitable purposes of NARAL Pro-Choice America.

fields.name: National Right to Life Committee
fields.description: Devoted to disseminating information and support for pro-life issues.

fields.name: National Right to Life Educational Trust Fund
fields.description: Educates the public about abortion, euthanasia, infanticide, and other related issues within the scope of bioethics.

fields.name: Planned Parenthood Action Fund
fields.description: To protect women's health and reproductive choice through advocacy.

fields.name: Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice
fields.description: Provide information and education in regards to reproductive choice.

fields.name: Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice Educational Fund
fields.description: Provide information and education in regards to reproductive choice.
